Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.
Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE

Nine lines of Greek text are preserved, almost complete, unevenly centred on the stone.
The letters are neatly and regularly cut, and of standard Hellenistic form, without serifs. Epsilon is notable for having a detached middle bar; beta is not closed.

Carefully carved letters, with minimal use of serifs, most visible on tau and chi; the iota adscript at the end of line 2 is small and mid-line; omicron is rhomboid in form, the hastae of the mu are all angled.
Later first century BCE or earlier first century CE

Guidlines are preserved clearly on fragment (a), faintly on fragment (b) and not on fragment (c). Line 3 of Fragment (a) shows compression of the final letters prior to the raised margin on the right.
Elegant and neatly v-carved letters with a generally wide module, and pronounced wedge serifs.

Eight lines of Greek letters, with the first two lines slightly indented compared to the rest, and a vacat below.

Deeply incised letters, slightly elongated. Alpha is extended at the top, with straight bar; epsilon is in form of a four-bar sigma with middle bar extended to match top and bottom strokes; zeta is regular Z; theta rhomboid with full middle bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has all strokes off vertical, with the middle strokes not fully descending; omicron is rhomboid; pi has overextended crossbar; rho has rounded and closed head; sigma is regular four-bar; omega is rhomboid but open at the base.

The text fills the face of the stone, with a margin of 10mm on the left edge, and a margin along the top of 22mm. The first two lines are larger than the rest.

Second or earlier first century BCE, primarily on palaeographic grounds (Manganaro various proposed dates between the end of 2nd century BCE and end of 1st century BCE (Manganaro 1963 and Cebeillac Gervasoni suggest post 36 BCE, assuming that line 17 implies the status of Centuripe as Latin municipium, which seems doubtful); Dubois, IGDS, suggests early 2nd century).

Irregular letters, some of which are larger than the others (the Latin D, the Greek Β). In the Greek text, E, Θ (according to Ferrua's drawing), Ω are lunate, (Latin and Greek), A has a broken cross-bar, Ξ is cursive. 
                                From Ferrua's drawing, the abbreviation of ὑπατίᾳ is realized through a small superscript π above the υ.
The Greek inscription has the consular date of 455 CE. If, as Manganaro believes, the two inscriptions are not the Latin and the Greek version of the same epitaph, they are nevertheless contemporary.

The first part of all six lines of the Greek text are preserved, but none are complete.

The letters are uniform and well cut, with pronounced serifs. A hollow triangular interpunct is used between all the onomastic elements (but apparently not elsewhere in the text; spaces are however observed between words, with or without interpunct). Theta has a detached middle bar; omicron is full size; epsilon has a detached short middle bar; mu reaches almost to the lower line in the middle, and the outer strokes are vertical.

A single line of Hebrew is followed by 14 lines of Latin; the Latin text observes a more or less regular left margin, irregular on the right. The lower right and left corners contain small incised menorahs, with the last line of text between them consisting simply of 'overspill' from the preceding line, offset towards the right.

Letters generally neatly and regularly cut, with basic serifs on the long strokes. B is somewhat irregular in fomration, sometimes with equal loops, sometimes with smaller upper loop; C is large and open; E is narrow, with three short equal horizontal strokes; G has distinctive form of small C with a tail descending to lower right; M is formed of four equal diagonal strokes; P has a somewhat elongated frequently (but not always) closed loop, but some instances have a wide horizaontal foot also; Q is closed with a trailing tail;  R is usually closed, with a tail usually straight and extended but finishing above the line; S is frequently oversize. The two menorahs at the foot of the inscription are 15 mm and 23 mm (the left is incomplete).

Four lines of ancient Greek filling the upper portion of the face of the stone, with a consistent left margin, the right side more cramped and irregular. The lower part of the stone is blank.

Letters are somewhat irregular in size, with simple straight line serifs terminating most strokes. Alpha with both broken bar and straight bar; beta both open and closed with rounded eyes; epsilon quadrate with equal length strokes; theta and omicron are rhomboid; kappa has short arms; mu has vertical first and last, short middle strokes; pi has overhanging horizontal; sigma is quadrate lunate; omega is inverted cursive form, having the appearance of mu; the pi-rho ligature is used twice; staurogram at the end of the text.
Fiorelli, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Monumental letters without serifs, but with a widening towards the end of terminal strokes. Straight bar alpha; beta with equal loops, closed; epsilon with shorter middle bar; Mu with verical first and last, shorter mid-strokes; omicron consistently smaller and mid-line; rho with closed loop; sigma with slightly open top and bottom strokes, mid-strokes only part width; phi with a small elliptical eye.
In the period subsequent to the establishment of the co-regency of Hieron II and Gelon (i.e. after 241/240 BCE)

The text maintains a regular left margin, ignoring the irregularity of the form of the stone, and filling the space to the right; however, the cutter ran out of space at the end of the stone, and inserted the remaining letters of the word Δεκεμβρίῳ and the concluding staurogram, firstly at the end of line 2 (letter β) and then, under a 'paragraphos' line to the left of the main text of line 2, level with lines 3 (letters ριω) and 4 (staurogram)

plainly cut, relatively regular letters, in a curved groove rather than v-cut, without serifs. Alpha has an oblique crossbar, sloping down to left, and a horizontal stroke to left off the top of the letter; beta has closed eyes, the upper is smaller; epsilon is lunate (except for the first in line 5 which is rectilinear); zeta has regular Z form; kappa has near full-legnth arms; mu has cursive form; omicron is full size; rho has closed eye; sigma is lunate; omega is lunate.

Seven lines of Greek letters, with traces of red paint. Lines 1-3 are more formally / monumentally carved, from line four onwards the carving is lighter and less carefully laid out, rising to the right.

Simple, thinly incised letters without serfis or terminations. The letters become increasingly ireregular and variable in the final lines. Alpha has striaght bar but also broken and oblique bar; beta has closed roughly equal eyes; Epsilon is quadrate with equal length bars; Zeta is Z in form but irregular; theta is ovoid with full straight bar; kappa has shorter arms; omicron mostly slightly smaller than other letters; sigma is lunate but square in form, lower bar slanting downwards, except for the irregular curved instance end of line 2; omega is in the form of a w, but formed entirely of straight lines and right angles. interlineation is highly irregular throughout.

The text is laid out in a single column, with a consistent left margin, with every second line indented by c.1 letter; the right margin is irregular.

Letters are plainly cut with minimal serifs and a square module. Alpha has straight bar; beta has equal closed loops; epsilon sometimes has equal length strokes, sometimes shorter middle bar; theta is full size, slightly elliptical, with plain cross-bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only half-descending; pi has overlapping horizontal, equal length vertical strokes; rho has closed eye of moderate size; sigma has horizontal upper and lower strokes; phi has an ovoid eye of varying size and extended vertical; omega varies between teardrop, rhomboid and small circle, always closed with horizontal baseline.

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.
Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content.

Decree in honour of a gymnasiarch
The text, occupying 47 lines, fills the upper two-thirds of the main rectangular portion of the stele.

The lettering is tight, both in between letters and in interlinear spaces. The first two lines are larger and more spaced, though not necessarily more precise in execution. Alpha appears with both a straight and a curved crossbar. Interchangeable use of four-bar and lunate sigma, often in the same line, often close together. Interchangeable use of square and lunate epsilon, same variability and position as with sigma. There is occasional omission of the middle bar of a lunate epsilon, particularly in between two sigmas, resulting visually in the combination CCC. This occurs both at the beginning and end of lines, and does not seem to correspond to textual cues. Omega is mostly rhomboid or ovoid, occasionally round, though the few round instances seem to be an execution issue with the ovoid variant rather than a stylistic choice.
(Later) second or first century BCE (Dubois and Cordiano suggest 1st cent. BCE)

Four lines of Greek letters, all crudely incised in the epigraphic field on the front face.

The first two lines are deeply incised, the second two very lightly incised. Alpha has straight bar, with an apex; epsilon has equal length horizontals; mu in line 3 has extended apices, in anticipation of the cursive form; omicron is circular in lines 1 and 3, angular (made up of straight lines) in lines 3 and 4; sigma is and open four bar sigma in lines 1-2, a quadrate lunate sigma in lines 3-4; phi has a small elongated eye; omega is open in lines 1-2, lunate in line 4. It is therefore likely that lines 1-2 were incised by a different hand from lines 3-4.
Potentially lines 1-2 (Hellenistic) predate lines 3-4 (late Hellenistic or Roman) by a century or two.

Four lines of Greek letters centred on the face of the stone, but with a leftward bias.

Very neatly carved wide, regular letters of a fairly square module, with minimal serifs and all letters of near equal size. Straight bar alpha; epsilon with only slightly shorter middle bar; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes descen half-way; omicron near full size; pi has equal length verticals with slight overhang on both sides of the cross bar; rho has large rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is circular and without over-extended vertical; omega is open and tear-drop shaped.
late second century BCE, or early C1 BCE, following Ampolo and Erdas (previously dated earlier by Nenci) and confirmed by parallel material

Remains of two lines of text preserved, with slightly irregular right margin to the lines.

Regular, deeply incised letters, of which alpha the widest. Borken bar alpha; epsilon has shorter middle bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only descending half-way; omicron is small and mid-line; rho is rounded and closed; sigma is regular four bar, with horizontal top and bottom, middle strokes half-width.

The text is set out over two lines on the lower part fo the front face of the slabe, in a field (4 cm high) demarcated from the upper part of the face by an incised horizontal line.

Small neat early Hellenistic letters, Alpha with straight bar, epsilon with short middle bar, zeta formed by vertical with horizontal bars top and bottom; Mu with four sloping strokes, full length; omicron, omega and theta all smaller than other letters; sigma with four equal strokes, top and bottom angled outwards; omega open with short horizontal tails.

Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
Later second or earlier first century BCE

Funerary inscription to Olos Papios Agatharchos
Three lines of Greek text. Text is not aligned with centre of stone, with a more significant vacat on right side of the stone than the left. End of line 1 obscured by damaged top right corner.
Some serifs are used, particularly on the epsilons. Spacing, especially in line 1, is irregular. Teardrop shaped omega in line 1. All alphas have a broken mid-bar.
Korhonen, 2001, Osservazioni sul collezionismo epigrafico siciliano

Two lines of Greek letters across the upper part of the face; the text fills the width of the stone on both lines

Somewhat crude, large letters, probably later Hellenistic: sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omega is closed, tending to elliptical in form; mu has vertical first and last strokes, mid-point descends half-way only; phi has small circular eye and extended vertical; kappa has short tails; alpha has broken bar; epsilon has short middle stroke

A koinon of priests honours [-?-] Lapiron, son of Diogenes

Three lines of Greek text are preserved: the state of the stone means that the beginning and end of all three lines is lost, and at least one further line could have been lost below. If there were any lines above these, they would have been on a separate block of stone.

The letters are regularly cut, with deep terminations to the strokes rather than extended serifs. Epsilon has a shorter middle bar, detached from the main vertical; omicron is very slightly smaller than the other letters; omega is almost, or completely closed, with a slightly elliptical rather than purely circular form.
Scibona, 2008, La chiesa e il complesso edilizio postmedievale
Scibona, 2009, Decreto sacerdotale per il conferimento della euerghesia a Nemenios in Halaesa
Prestianni Giallombardo, 2017, Un'epigrafe alesina recuperata (IG XIV 354)

Apollonia(?) honours Andron son of Thrasios
Four lines of Greek text, not quite centred, but lines 2 and 3 fill the width of the face.

Plain cut letters without serifs, of Hellenistic form. Alpha is straight bar (except possibly  broken bar in line 1); beta has two small closed eyes, with a gap between; epsilon has shorter middle bar; the form of theta is unclear (small circle or cross at centre?); kappa has small arms opening from the mid-point of the vertical; mu has curving middle strokes which reach down to the line, but vertical first and last; omicron is generally slightly smaller than the other letters; pi has equal length strokes without overlap; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omega is closed and very slightly elongated, slightly smaller than other letters.
Bonanno, 2008, Apollonia. Indagini archeologiche sul Monte di San Fratello - Messina, 2003-2005

l.2 α
The municipium of the Haluntini honours Gnaeus Pollienus
The text occupies five lines over the upper part of the front face.

Regular letters with a fairly square module, simply engraved without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; Kappa has full length arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with mid-strokes only descending half-way; omicron is full size; Pi has full length verticals, and slightly overlapping horizontal bar; omega is slightly open and nearly circular, with horizontal tails/feet.

The use of the term 'municipium' in Greek places this text almost certainly after the grant of Latin rights to Sicily by Julius Caesar (probably 46 BCE), but equally the use of Greek implies a date not later than the early Augustan period. The lettering is compatible with a late Hellenistic date.

The text is inscribed on three faces, the precise organisation of which remains a question of discussion. Battistoni 2020 and 2011, after Bormann, offers the most plausible and complete reconstruction, followed here: Section A in two columns on face I (left face for the viewer), continuing upper left on face III (central face for the viewer); Section B in a single column on face II (right face for the viewer); Section C, top of face III, followed by a large lacuna; Section D, lower left of face III; Section E.i, traces top right of face III, followed by a large lacuna; section E.ii, lower right of face III.

Dedication of an altar for Hestia
six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.
3rd or 2nd century BCE, lettering of the early-mid Hellenistic.

Statue base in honour of Olympis Mestos

The inscription is set out over four lines on the front face of the block on its upper half. The text is roughly centred, lines 1-3 filling the face, line 4 a single word approximately centered. Spacing between words is apparent and increases significantly in line 3.

The letters are regular and with terminal points rather than serfis, and are inscribed in parts in what is almost a punch style, rather than a chiselled groove. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has mostly equal legnth cross-bars; theta has a full-width cross bar; kappa has full length bars; mu has vertical first and last, three-quarter length mid-strokes; omicron is full-size; pi has eual length verticals; rho has fair-sized closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega is rhomboid and closed.
Later Hellenistic, later second or first century BCE?

Inscribed statue base for Gaius Claudius Marcellus

The text is laid out over two lines, off-centre, with the first line set 2-3 letters in from the left margin, the second, longer line c.4 letters in from the left margin. A large single letter appears to sit centrally to the face of the block immediately below lines 1-2.

Simply carved letters, without serifs, showing very slight curvature on the longer strokes (e.g. on alpha). The channels are not always smoothly cut, but rather staccato. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon with shorter middle bar; kappa with medium length arms (not full length); mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes to half height; omicron full size; sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes.

Edict of Flavius Felix Eumathus regarding the Thermae Achillianae

Greek text over four lines. The fourth line is shorter than the
                                        other three and ends with a vacat. The letters are broadly regular and neatly
                                        cut, but the sizing and spacing varies considerably across the four lines.

Letters are wide and omicron, phi, sigma, epsilon and theta are, on
                                    occasion formed by overlarge circles. Epsilon, sigma and omega are lunate. Xsi is
                                    formed in a distinctive, ornate fashion. Interpuncts are used occasionally, and
                                    formed of an 's' shape, sometimes forward, sometimes backward facing. Numerals are
                                    marked with a supraline.
434 CE (reporting an edict from the consuls of 433)

Six lines, of which lines 2-6 are indented by one letter compared to line 1, with a consistent left margin. The final line is shorter with the numeral larger and roughly centred. Mommsen suggested that the age formula in lines 5-6 was a later addition, seemingly for its slightly greater irregularity.
Lunate epsilon and sigma, cursive omega, with terminations rather than serifs; use of ligatures. Delta has extended top stroke. Some curvature of longer strokes and arms.

1ΕΚL(vac.)ΚΑΤ

The text is set out over nine lines, complete apart from the very
                                        ends of lines 9 and 10. Chi-rho symbols are set to the left of line two and the
                                        right of line three, and a star is set in the middle between lines one and two.
                                        There is some crowding in the final two lines. The text is approximately centred
                                        on the disc and the crowding at the end of line 8 in particular suggests that
                                        the stone was cut to this circular shape prior to engraving.

The letters are neatly but irregularly cut. Lunate epsilon, sigma and
                                    omega; alpha has a steeply left sloping cross-bar, the right hasta extended well
                                    above the rest of the letter; beta is tall, with two closed eyes, separated from
                                    each other. Supralinear lines are used above numerals and also in line 6.

Greek inscription recording enjoyment of a spring

The text maintains a clear left margin, laid out over three lines. The extended spacing in lines 1 and 2 has sometimes suggested to editors that the text divides into columns; however this is probably to compensate for the fact that lines 2 and 3 are shortened by the insertion of a large engraved palm leaf (20 cm high) on the right margin.

The text is engraved in large bold letters, with the topmost stroke often extended vertically above the letter on Α, Λ, Δ. Letter forms are somewhat variable within the inscription, with lunate and straight sigma used indiscriminately; epsilon is normally straight, but appears lunate in ΦΗϹΕΙΝΟϹ in line 2; alpha is normally straight but displays broken bar in ΕΥΦΡΑΝΘΗΣΑΝ in line 3; phi has an angular eye in lines 1 and 2 but a rounded eye in line 3; variation within texts is however common, and it is not necessary to assume that this reflects different hands in use within the text. Ligatures are employed several times in the text, which has been the source of several confused readings in the past.
3rd century CE or early 4th century CE (Manganaro)

Three lines of large letters across the upper part of one of the wider faces. The inscribed field is approximately 0.36 m high x 0.30 m wide. The first line of text is less clear, especially around the upper margin and at the right edge. A continuous horizontal line separates lines 1 and 2.

The letters are engraved in broad, rounded strokes (partly the result of weathering) and have a regular form. K has arms that do not quite reach to the top and bottom of the letter; E has strokes of equal length; A has broken bar. The text is either Latin or a mixture or Latin and Greek, given the presence of L in the second line.

The texts are not symmetrically laid out, with the left-hand text (this one) on the right half of the left hand block, set some way in from the left margin, and continuing in lines 2 an 3 onto the middle bloc; the right hand text instead starts half-way along the middle block and runs to the right end of the shelf. Both texts maintain a consistent left margin, with the first line starting one letter to the left. Spaces separate the words in line 4 of the left hand text.

Deeply incised letters with a fairly square but somewhat irregular sized module, and no serifs. Straight bar Alpha, epsilon with short sometimes detached middle bar; theta with detached cross bar; omicron a little smaller than the other letters; sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega nearly circular, and closed by a long cross bar.

1Ἀλέξιος τὸ σᾶ-
2μα
Inscription recording the neaniskoi of the gymnasium

The text fills the face available below the cornice (and seems likely to have continued below), with probably a consistent left margin, but a less regular right margin, and some cramping in order to fit words/phrases to the line (as e.g. in line 1).

The letters are mostly regular with a fairly square module and terminal points to the strokes rather than serifs. Alpha has broken cross-bar; epsilon has nearly equal bars; zeta in the form of an I with broad crossbars; kappa has short arms; mu has sloping outer strokes and half-height mid-strokes; omicron is nearly full-size, and consistently has a central dot (in lines 2 and 3 appears to have a line underneath); rho has rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes, and the mid-strokes extend almost the full width; phi is standard height, elliptical; omega is consistently a closed circle (without the central dot of omicron), sometimes on the baseline, sometimes traversed by the line.

Two lines of Greek letters, across the middle of the front face. The letters are aligned on the left margin, and are arranged in pseudo-stoichedon, i.e. vertically aligned.

Letters of the early Hellenistic or late classical period. Phi has an elliptical eye; alpha has straight bar; omicron is almost full size; sigma has widely diverging top and bottom strokes; theta is smaller than other letters, with a dot in the middle; omega is open; mu has diverging first and last strokes, and the mid-point only descends half-way; epsilon has short middle stroke. Words are separated on both lines by a three vertical points.

Orsi suggested the text was probably originally centred on the rock, but only the right part of three lines now preserved.

Large letters, rendered somewhat crude and deep due to the coarse stone. Sigma is four-bar with slightly open upper and lower strokes; omega is large, rounded and open with short tails; alpha has straight bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar; nu has three full length strokes, first and last vertical; mu has vertical first and last, but shorter middle strokes descending only half-way; omicron is full-size; rho has fairly large rounded, closed eye.
Later 4th or 3rd century BCE on the basis of the letter forms

Alpha is broad with straight bar; beta has distinct closed eyes, somewhat angular; eta is broad with outward turning lower strokes; theta is ovid with horizontal bar; mu is broad with vertical uprights, and the middle strokes only descending half-way; omicron is sometimes slightly smaller and above the line; sigma is lunate; omega is lunate.

Four lines of Greek letters, with a consistent left margin, starting at the top of the rear (smooth) side of the tessera, with small vacat below.

Small, slightly irregular letters without serifs. Lunate epsilon, sigma and omega; mu formed by four, equal slanting strokes; omicron generally slightly smaller than other letters; beta is closed, but with separated loops; rho is closed; xsi in form of a Z with horizontal cross bar; kappa has short equal length arms.
2nd century BCE, or possibly 1st century BCE (the letter forms look more plausibly second than 1st century)

Fragment of a bilingual dedication to Priapus

Five lines of regularly spaced Greek letters followed by three lines of Latin letters. The first two lines of Latin text follow the same spacing as the Greek text; the final line is seemingly centered, more widely spaced (with interpuncts) and separated by a slightly greater interval from the lines above. Although the top of the stone is damaged, the visible space above line 1 is greater than that between the following lines.

Regular, well-cut Greek letters with clearly defined serifs at the end of strokes: Omicron, omega and theta all have rhomboid form; in some instances this is actually a pentagonal form, flat across the top; Omega is open at the bottom; Sigma is four bar and regular; Epsilon has equal horizontal strokes; Alpha has broken bar; the diagonal of the Nu starts and finishes well below/above the ends of the vertical strokes. The Latin letters show the beginnings of the move towards cursive forms: M has extended upper strokes and the midpoint reaches to the bottom of the line; A also has extended upper stroke and lacks a cross-bar; O is rounded, in contrast to the Greek text, as is Q with extended tail; P is open; R is closed; E has short upward slanting strokes; L has a long foot, forming almost a C.
Scan of photo in NSA 1922 p.494 fig.2

The left margin of the text is carefully justified, but the right margin is very uneven, with several extensive vacats at line end.

Regular small letters of generally consistent size, deeply cut with pronounced terminal serifs on some strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, occasional extension of apex; beta appears open with rounded but not fully circular equal loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar, and upper and lower strokes often curve outwards at the ends; theta is ovoid with complete horizontal bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; mu has middle stroks joining well above the line; nu has the lower right angle above the line with shorter right vertical stroke; omicron is smaller and above the line; pi has shorter right vertical; rho is closed with generally circular eye; sigma has upper and lower horizontals curving slightly outwards at the ends, and the middle strokes often form into a single curving stroke; phi has a rounded eye, with the vertical extended, up to 17mm; psi has extended vertical and straight arms; omega is small, rounded, above the line, and open, with generally horizontal tail strokes.

20 lines of text on side (a), filling the face, some lines spearated by horizontal lines; 5 lines of text occupying the top part of side (b), with a large cross below, the remainder of the face blank.

Alpha tending to cursive (crossbar descending to lower left corner); eta variously standard or cursive (as a reversed N); nu is consistently reversed; theta, circle open above and blelow with cross bar overextended; kappa, upper bar joins lower left, lower bar attached to the upper bar; mu sometimes cursive; epsilon lunate; simga lunate; omega uncial.

The text is engraved on the upper surface of the stone (a second text on the front face); a large circular hole intrudes into the first visible line of the text, and the stone is broken away on the right side of the upper part, so the original extent of the text is unclear, but there appears to be a vacat after the third visible line

Plain letters of the middle Hellenistic period: Pi has verticals of equal length; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omicron is small and mid-line; epsilon has a short middle stroke; mu has vertical first and last strokes, while the middle point only descends part way; alpha has both broken and straight bar

A gymnasiarch crowns a group of youths

15 neatly carved lines of Greek letters, of which the first four are larger. There appears to be a slight vacat at the top; lines 1-3 are indented by the equivalent of 1-2 characters at most; from line 4 onwards the left indentation increases, with clear vacats after lines 5 and 6, and a fixed left margin (c.7 cm vacat) from line 7 onwards; a vacat is consistently inserted between each name in the list from line 7 onwards.

Elegant letters with minimal serifs/terminations visible on longer strokes (e.g. on tau, sigma and epsilon). Alpha has straight bar; beta has smaller upper loop, with the two loops connected without meeting the vertical; epsilon has shorter middle bar; theta is a full-size circle with a detached horizontal stroke at the centre; kappa has full length arms; mu has near vertical first and last strokes, with the middle strokes meeting a small way above the baseline; xsi is formed of vertical with three horizontals, the middle one of shorter length; omicron is full-size; pi has equal length vertical strokes; sigma has horizontal topo and bottom strokes; phi is ovoid, with vertical taller than other letters (14-15mm); omega full size, near circular, but open at the base. Traces of a secondary text include lunate epsilon (see commentary).
Museo di Archeologia dell'Universita di Catania
Photo J. Prag 2016-05-12, by permission of Museo di Archeologia dell'Universita di Catania

The inscribed face is maximum 0.26 m high and 0.497 m wide. The text is extremely irregular and uneven in its layout, with letters of varying size and the horizontal of the lines very erratic. The text appears to observe the left margin with some consistency, but is extremely irregular on the right. The full height of the face is employed: the final line is squeezed.

The inscription is crudely engraved and inexpertly laid out on the face. The letter forms are primarily distinguished by their irregularity and the poor quality of the engraving. Theta is formed by large circle with single mid-dot; epsilon on occasion has a shorter middle bar; omega is notable in being consistently extremely open, with short horizontal tails (projecting outwards only); omicron is generally full-size, or nearly so, but also smaller; kappa has equal length arms which join the vertical, but do not generally extend fully to the top/bottom of the line; alpha is broad with straight bar; phi has a rounded closed eye; nu on occasion has a shorter right vertical, leaning outwards; sigma is either four straight bars (with top and bottom strokes open beyond the horizontal) or with the top and bottom strokes joined by a single curving stroke; rho is closed, with either a rounded or an angular eye; pi has a shorter right hasta; mu is in one case faint and compressed, in the other broad and composed of four short off vertical strokes; delta is either regular, or with the base line angled down to the right.
Photo J. Prag courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale di Adrano

Thinly incised broad letters of regular height, without serifs or marked terminations to the strokes. Alpha has straight bar; Beta has closed loops, in the second instance separated from one another. Sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting slightly over halfway across.
Letters of the 3rd century BCE; the apparent double kingship reference suggests the Hieronian period

Four lines of Greek letters; the text appears to be centred on the stone, with slight vacat below.

. Based upon the single published photograph: regularly and neatly carved fine lettters without serfis or significant terminations. Alpha has straight bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes descending halfway; omicron is small and mid-line; sigma has diverging top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting at half width; omega is nearly full height, slightly ovoid, open with short horizontal tails. No editor records the size of the letters.
4th century or 3rd century BCE based on the letters.

Statue of Demeter with inscribed base

The text is engraved over six lines on a flat field 30.3 cm wide and 12-13 cm
                                        high. The left and right sides of this field are cut smooth, the upper and lower
                                        edges are uneven. The lower right and left corners are slightly damaged. The
                                        inscription is intact apart from damage to the middle of line 1 where the upper
                                        front edge of the plinth has been damaged. There is a clear vacat to the bottom
                                        and right of the text. The first line is larger and extends to left and right of
                                        the rest of the text. Lines 2-6 have a consistent left margin.

Alpha has broken bar; epsilon and sigma are lunate; omega is lightly but clearly
                                    rhomboid; omicron is smaller than the other letters and sits above the line; phi is
                                    extended well above and below the line.

Neatly painted square letters with short serifs, painted in the style of stone cut letters. Alpha is broad with straight bar; Epsilon has equal length horizontal strokes; theta is ovoid with a full horizontal bar; kappa has arms that are not quite ful length; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes nearly reaching down to the line; pi has equal length verticals; sigma is four-bar, of equal length, top and bottom strokes horizontal.

Four lines of text are preserved, with uneven left margin, suggesting that the text was centred on the stone prior to the later recutting. The letters reduce in size especially in the fourth line.

5ίου
The people of Tauromenion honour Nymphodoros son of Eukleides
Three lines of Greek letters, centred on the stone in the upper half of the front face, with some spacing between words.

Letters are fairly deeply incised with terminal points rather than true serifs. The module is slightly irregular, with line 2 smaller than lines 1 and 3. Alpha consistently has broken bar; omicron is full size; mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes only descending half-way; epsilon consistenly has an overextended top stroke, and a short middlebar; omega is a closed circle on top of the base line; theta is a full circle with short detached crossbar; phi has a small eye with extended vertical; kappa has full length arms.

The dating is somewhat disputed: the individual is commonly identified with the three-time stratagos of the city in  = IG XIV.421, for years 68, 82, and 97. However, the anchoring of the stratagoi list in absolute terms is less certain, even if the start date is generally agreed to fall somewhere in the middle or later third century BCE. If that date is accepted, and assuming the identification of the stratagos with the individual honoured here, then the date should fall somewhere in the first half or middle of the second century BCE. However, Battistoni (2020 p.176) rejects the identification, on the grounds that in his view the palaeography of this inscription is incompatible with such a date (he considers it to be palaeographically more recent than the base for Marcellus of the 70s BCE, IG XIV.435 = ). Palaeographic arguments seem weak in this context (and contrast the discussion of Muscolino 2009-2010, pp. 440-444, who reaches similar conclusions to those presented here) and the identification seems plausible, suggesting therefore a date between, very approximately, 200 and 140 BCE.

3εὐνοίας (vac.1)ἕνεκεν
The people of Tauromenion honour Nymphodoros son of Philistion
Four lines of Greek letters of equal height, centred on the upper two thirds of the front face of the base.

Deeply incised letters with a regular module (although with a little bit of cramping in lines 2 and 3) and of even height throughout. Terminal serifs of a simple wedge form. Alpha is consistently pronounced broken bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar, only lightly connected, with slight overlap of the top and bottom bar; theta is a full circle, with a short detached mid-stroke; kappa has shorter arms (especially the lower arm); mu has vertical outer strokes, with the middle strokes extending three-quarters of the way down to the base line; omicron is full size; pi has slightly overlapping crossbar, with equal length verticals; rho a large rounded eye; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with a slight extension at the join of the mid-strokes; phi has small eye with slightly extended vertical; omega is slightly smaller than the other letters, tear-drop shaped, joined to the base line (but the eye does not close before the baseline)

Perhaps second century BCE from the palaeography, and likely to be approximately associated with the base next to which it was found, ISic003124. The individual is not directly attested in the other Tauromenion texts, but the name Philistion occurs repeatedly, with Philistion son of Philistion holding the position of stratagos in year 94 of IG XIV.421 = ISic001246; since that Philistion is also given the ?demotic ΣΠΑΡ, this could be that man's son, which would suit a date in the middle of the second century or a little later (cf. Muscolino 2009-2010 p.441 with n.117).

The Syracusans honour King Gelon, son of Hieron II

Three lines of finely carved Greek letters, centred on the stone (line one with short vacats at beginning and end, line 2 fully filling the face of the stone, line 3 centred with substantial vacats before and after.

Elegant wide and very regular letters with thinly carved strokes. Broken bar alpha; beta with equal sized loops; epsilon with short middle bar; kappa with short arms; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes to half-height; omicron normally full size but small in line 2 (compression a factor); rho with almost fully rounded eye; sigma with approximately horizontal top and bottom strokes or very slightly open; omega full-size rounded and open with straight feet.
Gelon with title of basileus (241/0-216 BCE)

Ten lines of Greek filling the available space, decreasing notably in size in the second five lines

The letters are engraved in a fairly plain, square fashion, with simple serifs. Alpha is mostly with broken bar, sometimes with an extended upper serif, although there is a straight bar example in line 7 and in lines 8 and 10 straight bar descending to left foot; beta is closed, with larger lower eye, generally horizontal along the base; delta varies between regular triangle and oblique lower bar with extended serif above; epsilon has straight bars of equal length, except for instances in lines 9 and 10 when it is lunate; theta is ovoid with connecting straight bar; kappa has short tails; lambda sometimes has an extended upper serif; mu varies between a form with vertical first and last hastae and short middle strokes meeting above the line and cursive form comparable to a lower-case mu in line 9; omicron is full size in the first few lines, but increasingly is smaller and mid-line; sigma is consistently lunate, but more often formed of three straight strokes; less often a single curved stroke; omega is consistently lunate, and sometimes smaller and mid-line. The eta and nu are in ligature in lines 5, 6 and 7. In line 5 the omicron in the final word is inscribed above the other letters (due to omission?). The last two/three words of the last line are enclosed between a pair of christograms. Small hedera occur in lines 1, 3, 5, and 10.
Later 4th — 5th century CE (The tombs of the necropolis are dated to the late 4th and 5th century CE (Tigano 2008b: 49) and the inscription easily fits within this date range.
Manganaro Perrone, 2006, Epigrafe in greco di IV sec. d.C. di Alesa (Sicilia) in versi e prosa, per la morte di Eirena Philandros, "carissima a Botis boio-celtico"
Scibona and Tigano, 2008, Alesa Archonidea. Guide to the Antiquarium

13 lines of Greek letters, with a regular left margin, set out in pseudo-stoichedon, and a vacat at the end

regular quadrate letters of the Hellenistic period, well spaced. Omicron is smaller than the other letters and above the line; omega is formed of a small slightly elongated circule, closed below by a long horizontal; epsilon has a shorter detached mid-bar; theta has a short detached central line; tau shows some light separation between vertical and horizontal; kappa has almost full length tails; alpha is very broad, with wide low horizontal bar; mu has vertical first and last strokes, and the middle strokes do not descend fully to the line; phi is rounded, with a tall vertical; pi has a slightly overlapping horizontal; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes.

Honorific inscription for Marcus son of Publius
The left side of six lines of Greek text are preserved.

The letters are neatly cut, with light serifs. Omicron is full size; pi has equal, full-length hastae; mu has vertical outer hastae, but curving middle hastae, which do not always reach to the line; the central bar of the epsilon is detached from the vertical and shorter than the other two.
honorific inscription for marcus son of publius

1ὁ̣ δᾶμο̣ς̣ [τῶν Ἁλαισίνων]
2Μάρκον [..]..[. 5.]
3Ποπλίου υἱὸν .[. 5.]
4εὐνοίας ἕ[νεκεν καὶ]
5εὐεργε [σίας] [τᾶς]
6ἐς α̣[ὐτον]
The text is neatly laid out with a clear left margin on a single field below the moulding; divisions in the text at lines 5-6 and 25-26 are marked by paragraphoi.

Letters are regular and deeply cut, with slightly prounced serifs at the end of strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, and occasional tendency to apex at the top; beta has equal sized, closed, shallow loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar and slightly outward pointing top and bottom bars; zeta is formed by a vertical with horizontals top and bottom; theta is slightly ovoid in form, with a complete cross bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; Mu has slightly inward leaning first and final strokes, with the middle strokes meeting well above the middle of the line; nu has a shorter right hand stroke, with the lower angle above the line; omicron is small and mid-line; Pi has a slightly shorter right hand vertical; rho has small closed eye, of varying form (rounded or elongated); sigma has slightly outward facing top and bottom storkes and the middle strokes are sometimes rounded at the join; upsilon has shallow spreading upper strokes; phi has a rounded eye, with extended vertical stroke; chi is consistnly slightly larger than other characters; omega open, slightly smaller and above the line, with horizontal tails. A horizontal stroke is visible above and the left of the first letter of lines 6 and 26.
2nd century BCE (principally on the basis of letter forms

(Following Orsi's apograph in his taccuino) Small regular neat letters with terminations to the strokes but no signficant serifs. Alpha has straight bar; Epislon has slightly shortened middle bar; Zeta is vertical with wide top and bottom horizontal strokes; Kappa has slightly shortened arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with the middle strokes almost reaching to the base line; omicron is full-size; Sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; Omega is round full-sized, and almost closed.
2nd or 1st century BCE by the lettering which is later Hellenistic

Letters hard to discern in photograph: Mu is large and wide of equal length sloping strokes; zeta formed with vertical upright stroke; omega small and widely open.
1Μέλισα Ζωπύρου

Remains of three lines of large Greek letters with regular left margin. The text is not perpendicular to the face of the block as it survives, either implying poor layout or else the block has been recut.

Large wide and square letters, regularly set out, without notable serifs. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar; kappa has short arms; omicron is slightly smaller than other letters and above the line; pi has equal length vertical strokes and slight overlap of the horizontal; rho has a small closed loop
later third or second century BCE

Funerary inscription for the son of Artemon
Remains of two lines, damaged at either end, seemingly centered

Regular square letters of even height. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar; mu has vertical first and last, with the middle strokes meeting mid-way above the baseline; omicron is full size; rho has small eye;  omega is broad and lunate.
More likely late hellenistic than early imperial (lunate omega not before the second century BCE and rare on stone so early)

Sikel inscription on wall of a tomb

The text is laid out on the right hand wall (as one enters) of the roughly rectangular chamber. Two sequences of letters run in the upper line from left to right and in the lower line from right to left, with a final letter below.
Archaic (the tomb is dated by typology only to the 7th century or early 6th century BCE)

The text is engraved on the left-hand wall as one enters the tomb, in a single line, from right to left, with two further large letters separated from the main text

Letters of the archaic Greek alphabet: sigma rendered with a single wavy line; of the two alphas, one is regular, the other the arrow-head form 'alpha siculum'. Of the main group, qoppa is the tallest at 130 mm; of the two alphas, the regular is 170 mm, the sikel form 110 mm

Inscription recording an architect called Proxenos

Four lines of Greek letters filling the surviving face, with a regular left
                                        margin, uneven right margin

Deep, square cut, regular letters showing features of both middle and later
                                    Hellenistic texts: alpha with broken bar; mu and sigma with parallel bars; pi with
                                    equal vertical strokes; omega closed as circle on the horizontal bar in line 3,
                                    above the bar in line 1; episoli and xsi with short middle bar; omicron smaller and
                                    above the line.

Contract for the sale of a house

The lines of text begin at the left edge of the sheet and run across to the right edge without margins. Although the original upper edge of the tablet is lost, the beginning of the text is likely preserved; it is unclear what the top margin was. The bottom margin is approximately as tall as is the text itself, i.e. the text ends around the midpoint of the sheet as currently preserved. The first four lines fill the width of the sheet and when the line ends in the middle of a word either the final letters are squeezed in (L.1) or the word is interrupted (L.3).

The top of the sheet is damaged and the first line of text is not well preserved, but does appear to be the first line of the document. The right margin is entirely preserved. The bottom of the sheet is damaged but the final preserved line of text does appear to be the last line of the document. The left margin is unknown, and it is an open question how much text is lost on the left side (see below in commentary). The text wraps and several words are continued fron one line onto the next, breaking roughly between syllables (Lines 4, 5).

Part of a caduceus of the city of Hi(p)pana

The text is incised immediately below the moulded ring near the top of the handle, with the word damosion running around the handle and the ethnic instead written down the handle, perpendicular to the first word (Manganaro appears to misinterpret Crispi, implying that the word damosion is written around the 'bottone', or moulded ring, but Crispi's text and fig.1 (reproduced in Manganaro fig.3) show it immediately below the ring).

In the drawing by Crispi, alpha has straight bar, nu is oblique, mu has four oblique strokes of equal length, omicron is full size, pi has longer left vertical, and sigma is four-bar with diverging strokes.

Decree in honour of Nemenios (copy A)

The inscription occupies the large field between the two columns; the upper part of the inscribed field also contains an engraved laurel-wreath, with the text of the initial lines arranged in and around the wreath (the precise arrangement differs slightly between the two copies). There are clear traces of a previous inscription underlying the existing text, and likewise most of the inscribed face shows the traces of having been beaten smooth prior to re-use.

The letters of line 1 are largest (c. 7-12 mm high); those of lines 2-7 smaller (4-7 mm), and those of lines 8-34 smaller again (generally 3-4 mm). Letters of line 1 are quadrate, with standard closed omega (Ε, Σ, Ω), and are broadly comparable to letters of monumental Hieronian inscriptions (i.e. c. 265-215 BC Syracuse); letters of lines 2-34 are lunate (ϵ, ϲ, ω). There are two instances of broken-bar alpha, in lines 3 and 7. Eta is frequently, if not consistently, rendered in a form comparable to a reversed nu (described by Scibona as a cursive type). The form of the letter pi is also distinctive (in lines 2 34): the right hasta regularly bent outwards at the lower end; the left hasta occasionally similarly bent outwards also. The letters are engraved throughout by means of chasing with a chisel (with a curved rather than triangular profile).

Decree in honour of Nemenios (copy B)

The inscription occupies the large field between the two columns; the upper part of the inscribed field also contains an engraved laurel-wreath, with the text of the initial lines arranged in and around the wreath (the precise arrangement differs slightly between the two copies). There are some grounds for thinking that the main bronze plate of B has been re-used. Firstly, the area of the inscribed field is visibly recessed compared to the surface of the remainder of the main plate (visible at both the top and bottom of the inscribed field), which would suggest that the original surface was removed in preparation for the inscribing of this text. Secondly, immediately above the top of the inscribed field (and outside the recessed area), but mostly obscured by the entabulature, it is possible to make out a number of engraved strokes. These may be traces of a wreath, similar to that in the upper part of the present inscription, but belonging to a preceding, now-erased, text.

The letters of line 1 are largest (c. 7-11 mm high); those of lines 2-7 smaller (3-7 mm), and those of lines 8-32 smaller again (generally 3-5 mm). In l. 1, epsilon and sigma are quadrate (Ε, Σ), but omega is lunate (Ω) – contrast A with closed omega; in ll. 2-32 all three letters are lunate (ϵ, ϲ, ω), as in A. There are a number of minor variations in letter-form compared with A: delta shows a marked tendency to include an apex, which is found irregularly also in alpha and lamda; eta almost always takes the standard form in B (in contrast to the ‘reversed nu’ form in A); the xsi is similar; the tendency in A for pi to show curvature in the tail of one or both of the vertical hastas is not generally visible in B; broken-bar alpha is wholly absent from B (with the possible exception of line 4); the occasional equivalence between tau and upsilon in A is not found in B. B is inscribed by means of chasing with a chisel, like A. Terminal points at the end of strokes are however much less pronounced, or absent, which finds its counterpoint in the presence of apices or serifs on some of the letters made up of long strokes: as in stone inscriptions, serifs in part serve a functional purpose in assisting in the termination of the chisel stroke and its extraction from the surface. At the same time, the letters of B are generally thinner and so slightly more lightly chased (in so far as this is not simply a consequence of partial loss of the surface following damage in the fire and cleaning). In other words, there are grounds for thinking that, although the tools are the same, the technique and stylistic choices of the individual at work are subtly different from that in A, and hence that a different engraver was at work here. (This view is further encouraged by the slight differences in treatment of iota adscript and iotacism on four occasions, noted below.)

Entella 3 = Nakone A: decree of reconciliation

The text fills the face of the tablet. Lines 1-3 are indented by c.2 letters, and line 2 is surely complete and ended with a vacat occupied by the now lost nail hole upper right. Lines 34 and 35 appear compressed (implying the engraver was aware when he began line 34 that the text would run over; the vacat of line 35 is only partial, as line 34 falls towards the lower edge as it proceeds).

The several instances in which the cutter omitted one or more letters and subsequently inserted them above the already engraved text are notable (ll.8, 13, 20, 33); the phenomenon is not to be seen on the other tablets.

Entella 4 = B1, honours for Tiberius Claudius Antiatas

Entire text is sited on the main rectangular body of the tablet. The tympanon is occupied by a depiction of a triple-plumed helmet that intrudes down into lines 1-3, which it divides. The text maintains a left-hand margin of c.1 letter space, the left margin being ‘justified’, the right not. The empty space after the text is equivalent to 6 or 7 lines of text.

Entella 5 = A1, Entella thanks those who helped in the synoikismos

Lines 1-5 are roughly centred in the tympanon of the tablet. From line 6, the text is sited on the main rectangular body of the tablet. The left hand margin is ‘justified’, the right not.
